displayed_text: Family Member: Hi. Nice to meet you. Doctor: So you did your whole drive downtown here, all of that? Patient: Yes. I did. Doctor: How have you been feeling overall? Patient: I’m fine. Yeah. Did this once. (Laughs) Doctor: I know. Yeah. But, I still feel hurt that it didn’t- Patient: I know. I know. Doctor: You feel it too, I’m sure. Patient: You get the PSA yet? Doctor: Not yet. But last time it was going down. Patient: It was one, one, yeah. Doctor: So it went from one point one. Yeah. Patient: How long does it take to see the CAT scan?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, uh, they’ll just tell you what to worry about, what not to worry about, what fevers we worry about, what numbers to call, uh, what you can eat, what you don’t eat sometimes. I don’t know what the class really is about. Patient: Okay. Family Member: So, S_ had, um, he was getting chemo, he had a bathroom that nobody was supposed to use. Doctor: They’ll talk to you about that and teach it in the class, but I don’t think that’s an issue. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, what, what other questions do you have? Patient: I read the, the, the information which you gave me. I - trepeditation about the, my actual response to all of this. And, I won’t know that until we start. So. I really don’t have anything other than - I wanna get it started. It’s my fourth visit, and you’re a great guy. But, next time, I want you to stick a needle in my arm or something. Doctor: Yeah. So, yeah we, you know, my problem with this stuff is, you know, the hormone therapy does good on it’s own. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, we are adding more into it, so we can’t always tell you what the, um, adding in the chemo is gonna do. We can’t tell you what the surgery is gonna do. But, the outcome really is a number of men that don’t need therapy once we stop everything. Patient: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay and I did mention to you that your testosterone is also going up. Patient: Right. Doctor: However, I think given the fact that you’re feeling relatively well. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Except for that slight increase in fatigue, perhaps, and given that the PSA level is still very low, and I can’t imagine that a PSA of zero point five comes high to you or your body or you know increase the risk of this prostate cancer causing you know either side effects or um you know even death because it’s still quite low. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: My approach would be as we discussed last time to wait until that PSA level goes above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if we don’t. That may not happen for three months; it may not happen for six months. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: If it continues at the same pace it will probably happen – have the PSA will reach one point zero in the next year. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright, and uh, I do need to feel your tummy. (Dr. examining patient) Patient: Mm hmm. Doctor: And urine, no problems? Patient: No problems. Doctor: Ok. So should we go back on the chemo? Patient: I think so. I think so, 'cause-- Doctor: Yeah, because the last time your PSA came down and, you know, I think this tearing, like I said, it could possibly be from the chemotherapy, so-- Patient: I mean, if I'm doin' good on it, Doctor: It’s very much Patient: -let's keep goin'. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: He’s a good guy. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And then I went to see a doctor, L__, a radiologist, - Doctor: Mm hm. Mm hm. Patient: -and he’s going to radiate lymph nodes. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Now I get the impression he might do more than just the two that were were pressing right now. Doctor: I think that would be important for us because Patient: Yeah. Doctor: we may need to you know not treat them all and leave one so that you’re actually eligible- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -for the trial, which is a terrible thing to say.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Homemaker: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Homemaker

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: But, and it’s also a drug that if you take it long-term, you can get side effects from it, in terms of immune system. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: People tend to, you know, it tends to pop your appetite up, so you feel like you want to eat more. Patient: Give me the glasses. Doctor: It can also affect your skin. Some people, their skin gets very thin, and they bruise easily, particularly at the higher doses. So we, we could try the other one. I, I mean- Family Member: But you feel that would be less tiresome-? Doctor: Well, I just tell you my global experience with both drugs. Doctor: Has been it seems like both of them has a side effect, fatigue. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But my experience with using both drugs now, it seems like it’s a little bit more with the Xtandi. Uh, and the other question is, you know, we do have a couple of trials of Xtandi, uh, that, uh, I don’t know if you’re interested in going on another trial at this point. (Sound Door opens)

Family Member: What does cure mean? Doctor: Cure means that once we’re done all this therapy, the cancer is gone forever. Family Member: So, so yeah - Doctor: Which we won’t know for five, ten years. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Unfortunately you know you’re a survivor now. Patient: Right. Doctor: And it’s a diagnosis you’ll carry and you’re we don’t - not really out of the woods for five or ten years. Family Member: And then when you say not cured, if the cancer will come back would those people be considered to be in remission? Doctor: So if, so when we get his PSA undetectable and finished therapy, he’s in remission. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Even so on the hormones. Family Member: Uh hum.

Patient: I know. Doctor: No, you don’t, no. Patient: I don’t need the shot? Doctor: No. Patient: Good. Okay, I’ll just let it go. Doctor: Yeah, you just need rest, good narcotics, optimize your bowels and no crazy shenanigans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I appreciate both of you coming in. I really do. Patient: Well, thank you. I appreciate the time that you spend. Doctor: Oh, of course. I just wanted to wrap everything, yeah, because, you know, this always happens in medicine, right, we have one path and we’re like we’re going this way, it’s like no, everybody to the left, everybody to the left. We’re just regrouping. We’re just regrouping. Thank you both. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: I’ll get all the paperwork, get your scans set up and I’ll see you guys next week.

Patient: Oh, yeah. Doctor: We’re on camera. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Nice to see you. Patient: As long as it’s okay with you. Doctor: Yeah. It’s okay with me as long as it’s okay with you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’re just you know, we’re having our usual conversation that we have. What’s new? What’s the deal with going to Alabama and going straight, no breaks? Patient: I took breaks, but I just didn’t take enough. Doctor: Is your leg swollen? Can I take a look? Patient: Yeah. Might have to pull this down. Doctor: Why don’t you come on up here and see what’s going on. Patient: It’s up in here where it’s been.

Family Member: Ohhhh. Doctor: - outside that prostate gland. So it’s raising in my mind a good dilemma whether to do something for it or not. Patient: Uh huh. Okay. Doctor: On the one hand we have where if it keeps on growing it’s going to cause you major obstruction, blockage, things like that (pause) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And since you don’t have disease; you know if you had disease in twenty spots which is most people in this situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - with this kind of cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We would say forget why are we even bothering to putting you in harm’s way or side effects way – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - by trying to just take care of the prostate when everything else is out there. Patient: Right.

Healthcare Professional: Yes, okay. Doctor: So get in touch with ___ and/or myself. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And let me know that you’re coming actually the week after that. Like as soon as you feel you kinda know and then if we do go down the route of radiation therapy I can refer you to the radiation oncologist here to do that treatment. Patient: Okay, and now what would your role continue to be when I move to another physician? Doctor: Yes, I don’t deliver radiation therapy since I’m a medical oncologist. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So in the short term you go down that route and do the other therapy and they monitor you on that, and then once that part of it’s completed you’d come back to – Patient: Um hum. Come back to you, okay. You stay in the loop somewhere. Doctor: My hands Dr.__ is also going to be in the loop because he is the one who referred you. Patient: Yes, yes, I’ll have to; I’ll make an appointment with him. I saw him about maybe about six weeks ago and he had mentioned that they were starting up some trials in GW. I’m more comfortable where I am now, to be very honest with you. Doctor: Uh hum.

Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, I, I say plan for three hours, but you know, if we do the Tuesday visit and clear you, then your other visits it can be the shorter end of things because they know you, they expected you, they’ve cleared you. Patient: Yeah, we’ll get into the pattern and we’ll just - Okay. Doctor: But, we’re not using, uh, uh a port. You know, we’re just going to use your regular vein. So, that would be something else that if your veins are too tough to get, uh, something like that. Patient: I’ll tell you that the phlebotomist that did it today was probably the least painful stick I’ve ever had. Doctor: Do you have any other questions? Family Member: No. Doctor: Anything else? So, uh, uh, Family Member: So you definitely did get something from the insurance company on the chemo? ‘Cuz Healthcare Professional: Yeah, the chemo, ‘cuz he’s -- Family Member: You know, what we have doesn’t show that. Healthcare Professional: No, so what you have was something that you, that has to be preauthorized. The chemo is part of the whole, um, clinical trial package, so you don’t have to have preauthorization.

Family Member: You know you said Provenge is off the table but he keeps asking why. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Patient: I forgot about that, yeah. Family Member: Because the doctor said. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, no. When your PSA kind of creeps up a bit too high and you’re not as controlled and your symptomatic that’s not the group that benefits the most. There’s a kind of small amount of cancer, small amount of PSA, kind of like less than 22 would be ideal. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And then no pain. So, you’re the asymptomatic person Patient: Okay. Gotch ya. Doctor: and like uh, I got cancer, what, oh, perfect Provenge candidate. But you could get there again once like so he said can I get Provenge after Xofigo. Sure, if your pain was controlled. Even if your PSA wasn’t so low, having discomfort puts you in a different group. It just means your cancer is not behaving and having it go up on treatment is different than you not on anything and having it go up Patient: Okay. Doctor: and at this moment it’s not behaving. Patient: That’s why I’m always like at that time when I was low or no pain and that’s why he was thinking that’s what we…

Patient: Yeah. Right. Right. Yeah. Not too much. Doctor: Not too much. Yeah. (Laughter) Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Everything went okay and smoothly? Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. I’m fine. Yeah. Patient: So we get the shot right here? Doctor: Yeah. Yes. So how do you like the new trailer? Slowly, then the scans, everything is going to move here. Patient: Really? Doctor: Two years. Patient: Two years? Yeah. Family Member: Are they building a bigger building? Doctor: They are. Okay. That’s fine. Going to expand quite a bit. We were kind of bursting at the seams there so they needed to do it, but it’s going to be on a much bigger scale.

Patient: So, I say, yeah, I tell her can she get a script so I can call my insurance and see where I can get a cheap one at. Doctor: Yeah. I don’t think I will be able to justify a scooter for you. Okay? Based on just this disease. Believe me, I have given that script to other people, and it has not worked for people who are sick or older than you. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, I don’t think it will work. Okay? Uh, beyond that, if you want to see a neurologist, get tested, and see if they would be willing to give you, that’s perfectly okay with me. Patient: Uh, what, a what? Doctor: Neurologist. A nerve specialist. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they have to show that either your nerves are not working, your, uh, legs are not working, something or the other before we Patient: I wonder why they ain’t working good. Doctor: Yeah. So, they will say, “Did you try a walker? Did you try a this or that?” Patient: I, I, uh got a cane. I had a walker. Doctor: Okay. Now,
